docs.lead_paragraph: If you think body checks are injuring young hockey players, you may be missing the real hazards. Most injuries, a new study reports, are caused when players collide with the boards or, by accident, with one another, raising questions about whether bans on body checking, the blocking or bumping of an opponent, for younger players make sense. The study, led by Dr. Barry Willer of the State University at Buffalo, appears in Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise.

headline.main: Spotlight on the Real Hazards of Youth Hockey

docs.snippet: Most injuries to young athletes are caused when players collide with the boards or, by accident, with one another.

docs.lead_paragraph: As an author of several books about thyroid disease who also moderates a Web site on the topic, Mary J. Shomon gets more than 1,000 e-mail messages a week. ''I hear from people all the time who are fighting to be treated,'' said Ms. Shomon, a patient advocate. Most of the postings on her online message board are from women who report weight gain, fatigue, memory problems and depression. Many say they have thinning hair, dry skin and cold hands and feet. These are classic signs of an underactive thyroid, or hypothyroidism. But the patients say their doctors will not prescribe medicine because their blood tests are normal.

headline.main: For Thyroid Hormones, How Low Is Too Low?

docs.snippet: Setting the bar for the diagnosis and treatment of a failing thyroid, the gland in the neck responsible for secreting metabolism-regulating hormones, is proving difficult.

docs.lead_paragraph: When a person is lying, distinctive changes occur in the digestive tract, researchers have determined. The standard polygraph test, often criticized as inaccurate, may be improved if it is combined with a test for the stomach changes, they say. The findings were presented last week at an American College of Gastroenterology conference.

headline.main: Gut Reaction: Lying Is Tied to Digestive Changes

docs.snippet: The standard polygraph test, often criticized as inaccurate, may be improved if it is combined with a test for stomach changes induced by lying, scientists suggest.

docs.lead_paragraph: Paula Schneider was 38 when she developed what doctors first thought was carpal tunnel syndrome. But soon the trouble she had moving her right arm spread to her neck and back and then the whole body. She lost control of her limbs, head and torso, leaving her unable to walk, sit, eat or do much of anything. It was as if her entire body had been inhabited by jitterbugs that determined her every move.

headline.main: New Efforts Help Patients Get Back in Control

docs.snippet: When the body moves of its own accord, or refuses to move at all.

docs.lead_paragraph: People who are on dialysis are much more likely than those who aren't to have close family members who are also suffering from kidney disease, often without any symptoms, a new study finds. The researchers, writing in the current American Journal of Nephrology, suggested that if doctors treating dialysis patients began screening their high-risk relatives, many other cases of kidney disease could be slowed or prevented. The study was led by Dr. Barry I. Freedman of the Wake Forest University Baptist Medical Center.

headline.main: Doctors Issue Alert to Dialysis Patients' Families

docs.snippet: People who are on dialysis are much more likely than those who aren't to have close family members who are also suffering from kidney disease, often without any symptoms, a new study finds.     The researchers, writing in the current American Journal...

docs.lead_paragraph: A new drug for acne, Aczone, was approved in July, but with a catch. The Food and Drug Administration said it would require that patients first be tested for an enzyme deficiency that could put them at risk of developing anemia from the drug. The age of personalized medicine is on the way. Increasingly, experts say, therapies will be tailored for patients based on their genetic makeup or other medical measurements. That will allow people to obtain drugs that would work best for them and avoid serious side effects.

headline.main: A Special Drug Just for You, At the End of a Long Pipelin

docs.snippet: A new drug for acne, Aczone, was approved in July, but with a catch. The Food and Drug Administration said it would require that patients first be tested for an enzyme deficiency that could put them at risk of developing anemia from the drug.     ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Living with an unrelated adult, especially an unrelated man, substantially increases the risk that a child will die violently, researchers reported yesterday. According to the study, children who live with adults who are not biologically related to them are nearly 50 times as likely to die at the adults' hands as children who live with two biological parents, the researchers said.

headline.main: Unrelated Adults at Home Increase Risk for Children

docs.snippet: A new study suggests that living with an unrelated adult, especially an unrelated man, substantially increases the risk that a child will die violently.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Antibacterial soap works better than regular soap. THE FACTS What happened to plain old soap? Studies show that more than 70 percent of liquid hand soaps sold are now labeled antibacterial, and Americans seem increasingly willing to pay a premium for them.
docs.snippet: More than 70 percent of liquid hand soaps sold are now labeled antibacterial, but are they worth the extra money?

docs.lead_paragraph: Pediatricians routinely screen children for hearing problems, but what happens when they find something wrong? A fair amount of the time, nothing at all, a new study suggests. Writing in the current Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine, the researchers reported that when they reviewed more than 1,000 hearing tests given at eight medical practices -- three associated with a university -- more than half of the children who failed were not sent for follow-up examinations.

headline.main: Hints of Hearing Problems Are Often Ignored

docs.snippet: In a recent study, more than half of the children who failed routine hearing tests were not sent for follow-up examinations.

docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone remembers the first time. Everything sticks in your mind. She walked lightly into my office, a ballerina, youthful in her mid-40's. Her referring doctor had told her she had a lung tumor, yet she was as calm as a feather on a windless day as she sat down in front of me.

headline.main: A Physician's Challenge: Cancer Surgery, but 'No Blood'

docs.snippet: What is a doctor's primary obligation: to the morals of the profession - save lives - or to a patient's beliefs?
